repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body: I think that [this commit](https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/3aec761b21b13bf29a98575a0e32a665ba934986#diff-96da2032b81feec75e6282d512c63bf16d331b3fa4865d97317a27b3d31a0d1dL218-R220) was not reviewed and, accordingly, introduced the wrong behavior when it is checked not for the presence of a string in the result, but whether the string will return True as a boolean value.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -265,9 +265,9 @@ def test_locals(self):
         self.break_and_run('int(10)')
 
         result = gdb.execute('cy locals', to_string=True)
-        assert 'a = 0', repr(result)
-        assert 'b = (int) 1', result
-        assert 'c = (int) 2' in result, repr(result)
+        self.assertIn('a = 0', result)
+        self.assertIn('b = (int) 1', result)
+        self.assertIn('c = (int) 2', result)

comment_data.body: I can't figure out why we have to use normal assert here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -49,13 +49,13 @@ def nonfatal_error(self, error):
         self.assertTrue(self.expect_error)
 
     def parse_opts(self, opts, expect_error=False):
-        assert opts != ""
+        self.assertNotEqual(opts, "")
         s = u"def f():\n  cdef object[%s] x" % opts
         self.expect_error = expect_error
         root = self.fragment(s, pipeline=[NormalizeTree(self), PostParse(self)]).root
         if not expect_error:
             vardef = root.stats[0].body.stats[0]
-            assert isinstance(vardef, CVarDefNode)  # use normal assert as this is to validate the test code
+            self.assertIsInstance(vardef, CVarDefNode)

comment_data.body: I don’t really like this `False, "Invalid Cython code '%s' failed to raise an exception" % code`, I would rather raise an exception ...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -114,9 +114,9 @@ def test_invalid_number_literals(self):
                     # cython: language_level=3
                     ''' + code)
                 except CompileError as exc:
-                    assert code in [s.strip() for s in str(exc).splitlines()], str(exc)
+                    self.assertIn(code, [s.strip() for s in str(exc).splitlines()], str(exc))
                 else:
-                    assert False, "Invalid Cython code '%s' failed to raise an exception" % code
+                    self.assertTrue(False, "Invalid Cython code '%s' failed to raise an exception" % code)

comment_data.body:
If this fails, it will be unclear which is missing.
```suggestion
            self.assertFalse([f for f in funcnames if f not in xml_funcs])
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -240,33 +240,31 @@ def test_debug_info(self):
             funcnames = ('codefile.spam', 'codefile.ham', 'codefile.eggs',
                          'codefile.closure', 'codefile.inner')
             required_xml_attrs = 'name', 'cname', 'qualified_name'
-            assert all(f in xml_funcs for f in funcnames)
+            self.assertTrue(all(f in xml_funcs for f in funcnames))

comment_data.body: This changes the semantics. Previously, we didn't require the values to be strings (or something with a length). Now we do. Not sure if this was intended.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -124,10 +124,10 @@ def test_CythonFunction(self):
                          'codefile.SomeClass.spam')
         self.assertEqual(self.spam_func.module, self.module)
 
-        assert self.eggs_func.pf_cname, (self.eggs_func, self.eggs_func.pf_cname)
-        assert not self.ham_func.pf_cname
-        assert not self.spam_func.pf_cname
-        assert not self.spam_meth.pf_cname
+        self.assertNotEqual(len(self.eggs_func.pf_cname), 0, (self.eggs_func, self.eggs_func.pf_cname))
+        self.assertEqual(len(self.ham_func.pf_cname), 0)
+        self.assertEqual(len(self.spam_func.pf_cname), 0)
+        self.assertEqual(len(self.spam_meth.pf_cname), 0)

comment_data.body: Appending `$` changes the regex.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -239,7 +239,7 @@ def test_python_step(self):
         # be compatible
         frame_name = pyframe.co_name.proxyval(set())
         self.assertEqual(frame_name, 'join')
-        assert re.match(r'\d+    def join\(', result), result
+        self.assertRegexpMatches(result, r'^\d+    def join\($'), result

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -457,10 +456,10 @@ def test_cy_eval(self):
         self.break_and_run('os.path.join("foo", "bar")')
 
         result = gdb.execute('print $cy_eval("None")', to_string=True)
-        assert re.match(r'\$\d+ = None\n', result), result

comment_data.body: Appending the `$` changes the regex.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -457,10 +456,10 @@ def test_cy_eval(self):
         self.break_and_run('os.path.join("foo", "bar")')
 
         result = gdb.execute('print $cy_eval("None")', to_string=True)
-        assert re.match(r'\$\d+ = None\n', result), result
+        self.assertRegexpMatches(result, r'^\$\d+ = None\n$')
 
         result = gdb.execute('print $cy_eval("[a]")', to_string=True)
-        assert re.match(r'\$\d+ = \[0\]', result), result
+        self.assertRegexpMatches(result, r'^\$\d+ = \[0\]$')

comment_data.body:
This file is a copy from CPython. It should not be changed syntactically in order to ease future updates.
```suggestion
                assert sys.exc_info()[0] == ZeroDivisionError
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -974,7 +974,7 @@ async def gen():
                 DONE += 1000
                 yield v * 2
             finally:
-                assert sys.exc_info()[0] == ZeroDivisionError
+                self.assertEqual(sys.exc_info()[0], ZeroDivisionError)

comment_data.body: Yeah, sorry, forgot that the match only compares to the beginning
comment_data.diff_hunk:

         # be compatible
         frame_name = pyframe.co_name.proxyval(set())
         self.assertEqual(frame_name, 'join')
-        assert re.match(r'\d+    def join\(', result), result
+        self.assertRegexpMatches(result, r'^\d+    def join\($'), result

comment_data.body: Ok, seems reasonable
comment_data.diff_hunk:

                 DONE += 1000
                 yield v * 2
             finally:
-                assert sys.exc_info()[0] == ZeroDivisionError
+                self.assertEqual(sys.exc_info()[0], ZeroDivisionError)

comment_data.body:
Your code will work fine, but I think that if we want this to be more obvious we can use sets:
```python
set(funcnames) - set(xml_funcs)
```

(As well as use it instead of `issubset`)
comment_data.diff_hunk:

                          'codefile.closure', 'codefile.inner')
             required_xml_attrs = 'name', 'cname', 'qualified_name'
-            assert all(f in xml_funcs for f in funcnames)
+            self.assertTrue(all(f in xml_funcs for f in funcnames))

comment_data.body:
I can of course just use assertTrue, but it seems to me better to clarify.
But do we want to use anything other than a string / byte for this field?

         for literal in INVALID_UNDERSCORE_LITERALS:
             for expression in ['%s', '1 + %s', '%s + 1', '2 * %s', '%s * 2']:
                 code = 'x = ' + expression % literal

                     ''' + code)

commit.message: Use assert from unittest in TestStringIOTree.py and TestTestUtils.py
TestParseTreeTransforms.py: Check if the Debugger is "more robust"?

Revert "TestParseTreeTransforms.py: Check if the Debugger is "more robust"?"

This reverts commit a4cd370a5e75ab70d938778429934348aa7ca2c3.
